												Commandos 2 is one of few examples, where a sequel of the game turns out at least just as good, if not better, then the original idea.To be clear: if there is a single flaw of Commandos 2, compared to Commandos 1, it is low difficulty level.In a nutshell: the game is isometric sneaker strategy / logical game in real time, World War 2 themed, British commandos fight against III Reich and ... Japan, consists of ten regular missions, nine bonus missions (+1 regular mission 'bonus phase'), and two trainings, roughly 20-40 hours to beat.So what it is all about? The key idea remains the same: player has 1-8 (usually 3-5) commandos to control plays missions against 10-50 (sometimes 100+) soliders on the map being outmumbered and outgeared, the player must use silent takedowns without setting off the alarm, at least for most part of the mission. enemies have their own sight and hearing areas, most of the time the player approaches from behind, and in places which are isolated from another guards, this usually requires luring the guard out from crawded area, distracting anoter patrolmen or combination of both, all settled during the WW2, though with fictional history. One will for instance visit Asia and Pacific as a British commando.The commandos 'specialise' in following areas:  a dirty job guy aka Green Beret, stealth and melee combat expert,  a sniper, one shot one kill, can collect ammo from enemies,  a diver, can swim unnoticed in deep water,  a sapper, demolition expert,  a driver, gunner and tank operator, also handles "exotic" weapons,  a spy, covert ops expert, can dusguise himself as an enemy and chat the guards,  a thief, sneaker but with limited combat abilities,  Natasha, spy / sniper equivalent (shows up in three missions, where European officer would be too suspicoius),  a dog, another distractor but is cool.Compared to C1, all the commandos have shared set of skills, which includes: shoting a gun, machine guns and rifles (except for sniper rifle), stunning enemies with fist punch, carrying bodies, driving small cars, swimming and (limited) diving, using medpacks, disguise as enemy solider (though only the Spy can do this efficiently), distracting with cigarettes, decoy, etc.The commandos no longer seem to be rookies.This actually makes the game way easier, as a tight cooperation is no longer needed.On the other hand this varied set of skills adds a lot of freedom into the game, and one no longer needs to stick with the Green Beret.The game lost its deadly alarms and garrnison patrols, which were almost a signatue feature of the first part (and usually resulted in mission failure).The enemies are far less aggressive and leave a large time margin of error before opening fire.More then enough to get back to safety.They are more susciptable for diversion and there are more ways to distract them.So what did the game gained? Why it is still worth anything?A lot of freedom. A lot of equipment (compared to C1): smoke grenades, gas grenades, bottles of wine, sleeping pills, wire traps, landmines, bazookas, fresh meet (for guard dogs), binolucars.Gun blazing is now more possible, but stealth actions remain a tactics of choice (plus it is fun with all those toys).Possobility to explore and fight inside buildings.Ten unique missions (+ a couple of bonus), every single one has something which makes it distinctive (including a mission with no killing, whose objective is to steal enemy documents).Campaing progress menu, possiblility to replay a particular mission.Bonus objective, and item collections which unlock bonus missions.Commandos 2 introduced amazing (for its time 2001) interaction with the environment including: daytime / night time (only one mission), switch off the lights to hide in shadow,  frost (limited time to stay outside buildings, one mission only), search the shelves and boxes for equipment,  enter and expore buildings, get into the building through the door or windows,  sniper shot through the window,  climb a pole to move unnoticed, hide corpses in a pile of thrash, hide yourself under the table.The game still offers quick save + load, still used quite frequently. While it is a war game most of enemies can be stuned and knocked out without killing.On top of that the missions are scored based on time taken, damage, exploration and stealth level, including mentioned nonlethal takedowns.The game is almost 15 year old, and offers a maximum resolution of 1024 x 768, but on my 17'' notebook I find the video surprisingly good, mainly due to reasonable amount of details and limited 'graphical pattern reuse'.The music is finally present in the game and sound effect seem also fine, don't distract a lot.Flaws? low-to-medium difficulty level (even "very hard" difficulty is a mid-game of Commandos 1), The boxed Commandos 2 version featured short cienematics between the missions, which don't run in Steam version,I cannot tell if this is a common problem or just a config / codecs issue on my computer, When scaled to 16:9 display, the graphics gets a bit pixelized.Do not play if: you are allergic to old games / hybrids / isometric cameras.Do play if: well... just play!

												What other game can you command a squad of elite commandos, be in an 3D simulated isometric world, and explore the world, plus for it to actually be good? Well then, Commandos 2 is the answer you would be looking for. This game is able to capture that epic feel of being an elite commando, not one, not two, but eight. In a variety of missions all around the world, taking on the Japanese Empire in Asia and the Nazi Forces in Europe. This wide variety of missions are all housed on massive maps, with plenty of ways to tactically go through. As well, each map has bonus content hidden in each one, which unlocks even more maps for the astute players. The level variety, and enemy variety are amazing, with tactics unlimited, as well the music is sublime, unique to each level, and keeps the tone and gravity of the high stakes game of warfightering.The commandos themselves are a particularly interesting note to mention in the game. Out of all of them, there is only one American character, which is a nice deviance from the typical video game standard of making every character in WWII an American. The commonwealth is strongly recommended, france has their own few commandos, and even the USSR is represented. All together, the human interaction, and true comradery between these "Men of Courage" brings out their grin worthy character and qualities. Its that feeling that its more than just a game with pixels, that this is high stakes, that the world is there to be saved by you, and you alone.This is why the game can be appropriately recommended, because it simply is excellent. It doesnt hold your hand, its not gonna treat you nicely sometimes, but it manages to not matter. You keep pushing, you keep trying, you keep reloading. You need to, do you know why? Because the world is at stake, and you are the only one to save it, now get out there soldier, and kill me some Schutzstaffel.

Short version: 91%Better graphics, huge maps, simplified controls and less strict game mechanics were a great recipe for success for Commandos 2, even if the more hardcore fans were a bit disappointed with the more monotonous gameplay and low difficulty.Long version:Commandos 2: Men of Courage was the most successful entry of this series of isometric strategy/stealth World War II games about a small group of international soldiers sent behind enemy lines.The game features ten missions (plus ten bonus levels) with great map size and large variety in design and objectives. The levels have a more cinematic feel to them, thanks to replacing the short briefings with dialogues, and also adding small arcing plots.The general goal of the game remained: sabotage Nazi and Japanese forces, which can mean anything from blowing up a submarine to saving some POWs.To achieve this, you are usually required to get rid of all enemy soldiers on the map – mostly by stealth, but some segments require combat, and in some cases you even need to fend off invading forces. The latter ones don’t really fit into the game though, as they are more of a repetitive memory game that gets pretty boring pretty fast.The commandos themselves received an overhaul. Everyone retained their unique abilities, but basic actions like driving, knocking out enemies, and carrying bodies can be done by anyone.This was a double-edged sword. Many situations require team coordination, but this coordination mostly means throwing two packs of cigarettes to the floor and quickly hitting two soldiers on the head. This trick works for the majority of the game, leaving gameplay quite repetitive, especially when you need to do this on more than a hundred enemies.If you can live with this repetitive nature, the great map design will more than make up for it, giving you a memorable and quite long game for very little money.

												A huge and incredible jump following the success of Commandos: Behind Enemy Lines - And still looks just as exceptionalWe see a welcome return of much that made the first game amazing: A true David & Goliath situation where, using your wits and the skills of a handful of commandos, you must work your way through heavily-guarded encampments, cities and even Colditz Castle itself - eliminating enemy soldiers as you attempt to neutralise key targets, rescue captives and capture the enigma machine. Gratefully all of the commandos from the first game return, charming as ever, including a few extra faces. This goes way beyond point-and-click stealth - The game requires a lot of patience, careful planning and studying of enemy movements. For 10 missions (not counting bonus ones), there's a huge amount to do - so expect to divulge many hours into this... it's a beast!There's a ton of new features and abilities too - including completely revamped graphics and a superb soundtrack, the biggie is that you can now enter (and operate) within buildings - bringing huge levels of new scope to the missions. Each Commando also now has an 'inventory' and can carry / exchange any item (even if they cannot necessarily use them) and there's much more this time around in terms of raiding boxes / cabinets for useful items or pinching them off some guardsThe missions bring with them an exceptional variety too. Amongst the sneak-and-kill we're used to, the first night mission forces you to play without any killing. Another leaves you with just one Commando having to set free the rest of your companions, held captive in several different houses. You also get a number of 'defence' scenarios where you have to place your guys and a handful of friendly soldiers to defend against an attack force. It's varied and brings refreshing new elements to an already formidable gameI have two small gripes though. The first is that, compared to the original, it's not as difficult where you no longer have garrisons. Previously, patrols would start swarming the place if you set off the alarm - here, the consequence is less fatal. That's not to say the guards are any less dangerous, but you can sometimes ragequit a situation with a few well-aimed shots or explosives if you get fed up. The 'rooms' tend not to interact with each other much, so it splits up the levels into smaller easier-to-manage chunksThe second... Spike the rat (and a castaway with a trumpet). Come on... a specially trained rat that does backflips to distract enemy soldiers? You can get infinite uses, send it through doors and it pretty much distracts nearly any group... Talk about overpowered. It removed a lot of the challenge - not to mention being quite ridiculousTruth be told though, that's nit-picking. It's an otherwise exceptional title which successfully manages to retain much of what made the first so ground-breaking, whilst valiantly bringing in a cavalcade of new features and dynamics. Superb work

Posted: July 4, 2016
												This is one of those games that makes me wish there was a Neutral option in addition to Thumbs Up and Thumbs Down. My complaints about Beyond the Call of Duty apply to this installment as well: Too many shared abilities water down the puzzle aspect and difficulty. All of the characters have the means to: lure enemies away from posts and patrols incapacitate them non-lethally carry bodiesMaybe that doesn't sound like much but those three actions actually account for about 90% of dealing with enemies in this game.Overall, the word I'd use to describe this game compared to Behind Enemy Lines and Beyond the Call of Duty would be: complex. There is a VERY steep learning curve to controlling the characters fluidly. The hotkeys to their tools/skills span the entire keyboard and differ between characters. It took me a long time before I stopped stumbling over the controls during high intensity situations that required precise hotkey-ing.All characters now have "roleplaying game"-style inventories. Whereas previously all tools/abilities were displayed on the sidebar backpack, now there's a per-character inventory for carrying different objects and equipment. Characters can also carry equipment that can only be used by other characters, too. e.g. the Diver can hold bombs even though only the Sapper can use them. In addition, boxes, cabinets, chests, etc. are scattered throughout the map and need to be searched to find items/weapons and a set of unlock keys for bonus levels. All of that actually kind of annoyed me by padding gameplay time with what I feel to be filler material. There's a war going on here, and I'm trying to find scraps of photographs in random kitchen cabinets?Two new "characters" have been added to the starting lineup: A Thief and a dog. The dog has his own backpack/inventory space, does not agro enemies, and has a 'Green Beret's Decoy'-like function i.e. barking to draw attention. (-_____-) Come on, man! Really? Too easy. I enjoyed this game, I did, but I really can't help but feel that every installment drops a little bit further below the bar set by Behind Enemy Lines even as they add more and more "stuff". I can't stress enough how bad I think it is that the classes share so many abilities. The Green Beret used to be the only guy who could cause a distraction while being elsewhere by using the Decoy. Then they let everyone throw rocks and cigarettes. Then they created an almost autonomous Decoy: the dog. Used to be only the Green Beret and the Spy were strong enough to carry bodies. Now everyone can carry bodies. The only thing that only Tiny can lift is barrels now, and I never used them in this game because bombs were so abundant.The Sniper is.... still the only guy who can snipe. Phew.The Diver used to be the only guy that could pilot boats. Now anyone can do it. He used to have a silent and lethal albeit short-range weapon: the harpoon. Now the harpoon is only useable underwater. There are very few opportunities to use it. They combined his short-range lethal with his Knife to give you a Throwing Knife ability. Rarely useful because it is not silent.Sapper is still the only person who can use explosives but they took away his man-trapping ability and gave it to the Driver for some reason. They also took away his exclusive wire-cutting priveleges and gave it to everyone. Instead he's now the only guy who can detect and defuse mines.The Driver's original niche was being the only guy who could drive vehicles and the only one to use a machine gun. Granted, I never once used the machine gun because it's slow rate of fire and straight line spread made it borderline useless, but at least he could drive. Now everyone can drive. His exclusive abilities are: Rigging tripwire Setting mantrap Throwing knockout gas/smoke/incendiary grenades Digging pitfalls....Uhhh, since everyone can drive now, what do we need a "Driver" class for? He should be called the Trapper given his new skillset. It almost looks like they had too much stuff the Sapper would have needed to carry so they just spread it out and divided it with Tread because he wasn't doing much.The Spy is actually a little more useful here than in BCD. Once he has Distracted an enemy he can now command them to do two things: Look a certain direction or Walk a short distance to a specified location. You can literally Distract a guard and tell him to walk into a mantrap.The new Thief class has a few special qualities. He can crawl under barbed wire, he stole the climbing ability from Tiny,  he can climb in through windows, and deploy a Rat that will Decoy enemies in short range. He's also the fastest runner.I feel like the gang could really afford to ditch the Driver and the Thief and just divvy up their abilities amongst themselves.

												I don't quite know how a game published by Eidos 10 years ago is today considered "indie" but Commandos represents a genre of games that nowadays would NEVER get made (real-time tactical stealth?), and 2 is my personal favorite of the series. You're given a small team of units, each with unique and VERY limited abilities, with which you must infiltrate fairly large areas and complete objectives. Getting spotted with most characters means death/KO due to low health, and since everyone's usually needed for the plan to succeed, that means you restart the stage. Winning requires first just not moving an inch, watching the enemies patrol the entire map, and figuring out where to start. This can take a while but Commandos 2 at least has a few guys for whom you can decide "screw THIS," set off an alarm, and just MURDER EVERY NAZI AND JAPANESE YOU SEE. But at its core, this is a game about distractions, disguises, traps, & silent kills or KOs. It's The Great Escape, not Saving Private Ryan.

												Played this when i'm still a kid, and it's still as good as i remember it, the difficulty is a little hard though, but you'll get used to it. So basicly the plot is about a group of allied commando unit fighting axis in WW2. The mission ranges to sabotaging a submarine pen, blowing a bridge, rescuing VIP in a middle of warzone, and so on. You can also pick up items that can help with the mission, like finding bombs, guns, medkits, and such, thus giving it a bit of a RPG element. The gameplay really good, if you ever met with trouble like a soldier that always looking at the entrance to a door that leads to your mission goal, the door is in his line of sight and if you get in his line of sight he will alert the other soldier, you can kill him but the other soldier has his line of sight on the soldier that you need to kill, thus rendering frontal attack useless. So how do you get pass him? 												Commandos 2: Men of Courage combine the brutally long gameplay of its predecessors with modernized graphics. The game, while still maintaining the long mission length, somehow manages to be easier than Commandos 1.  There is more leeway for mistakes and as result Commandos 2 is less masochistic than its predecessor. That doesn’t mean this game will be easy on beginners though, in fact the tutorial and first few mission should hurt your ego if you think this game will be a cake walk. The graphic, sound effects and musical score are all very nice and varied. However, the game severely fails when it comes to clarity of objectives and pathetically easy enemy takedown patterns. In some missions the objectives are borderline invisible, so you may have killed all the enemies on the map, but if you can’t find the one specific npc, you will never leave the map. Overall a good entry level and modern commandos game, imo the best of the series regardless of a few negatives.

												Great game for the patient gamers!  I've always loved the Commandos series from the beginning. It wasn't until I learned how to properly play the game that I found the beauty in the gameplay. It's not a game you can just run around gunning all the Nazi's down and hope to prevail. It's a game where you rather setup your attack or simply go around the obstacle using whatever gadgets or tricks you have up your sleeve.  That is the beauty in the gameplay. You can make up many different ways to get to your next point. During this time you will spend patiently waiting, hiding behind something out of a guards view as you inspect your surroundings and the entire environment where you plan your move.   Each Commando has his own special abilities and reasons for use so you generally have to mix it up and figure out which Commando to bring to the situation at hand.   While the game can seem brutal hard, there is a quick save and quick load feature which is best to use often. I constantly found myself reloading after making a mistake and trying to figure out the best way to accomplish the task at hand.   While the game has aged quite a bit, it's still a great play for any gamer this day in age mostly because there is none quite like it. The backgrounds are solid looking pieces of work that can be rotated at 4 different angles while the troops, Commandos, and most interactive environment objects are full 3D. You can also go for 360 degrees when you are inside a building. This makes for great planning and inspection of the environments.  Overall, I recommend this game as I consider it one of the benchmarks of this type of gameplay. For those unaware, its' not turned based or pause the gameplay and figure out what to do. It's all in real time and 1 mistake can cost you the mission instantly. Although like I said, there is a quick save and load for a reason and be prepared to use it often. The beauty in the game is making the corrections of the mistakes you made to get by and the rewards for the success upon finally completing a mission. Great game!  For another game similar to this that I think did a great attempt at trying to be like Commandos, look out for the original Desperados.

												Fantastic game that I have replayed again and again. It takes liberties with actual WWII history, but that's just to establish its own lore within the context. That's not an issue, however. Instead, the main issues I have are recently inflicted by remnants of the developer (Pyro has since become a mobile developer). While the game was definitely dated graphically, I feel that, short of mods, it didn't need an update. Let alone a hokey, barely competent update that essentially fills the screen up with more pixels rather than actually increasing fidelity or anything like that. Yet that, too, is not the main issue I have with this game.It's the bugs. Newly introduced ones at that.First off, before they updated the game I was right in the middle of the "Saving Private Ryan" mission. I was totally amped to continue my progress when BOOM! An update comes out of the blue and totally kills my save progress. On top of that, you had to do pull some moves to even get the game to launch properly. Then when I started playing I noticed a number of things that popped up that I never encountered before. The minor things may include missing animations (Tiny & Lupin no longer 'sneak' when walking near enemies, which actually hurts immersion a little), to some audio cut-offs. Also, it seems that when you have a commando leaning against a wall (a stealth tactic in the game), they are prone to appearing through said wall to any enemy on the other side. Also, some things feel like they are missing, but putting my finger on those is an arduous task at this point and I think you, reader, may get said point, too.My biggest problems are the bugs that cause either the game to not move forward at all (case in point, 'Castle Colditz', where you have to combine parts of a secret plan and use a radio in order to trigger an evacuation condition that allows you to complete the level). Another problem I ran into that FORCED me to cheat was on the 'Bridge Over the River Kwai' level, wherein you try to interact with the model of the bridge in order to initiate that level's level completion condition. It crashes to desktop each and every time you try. So, frustrated as I was, I was forced to fire up the cheat mode in order to go to the next level. They changed that a bit too but it's nothing concerning to me. Unless the developers screw up the game enough to warrant using this feature in the first damn place, which they damn well did so the joke is on them.If the game worked as it should have, then I'd heap nothing but praise upon this title. It had been my favorite for over 12 years, and still is, in spite of the hackneyed attempts to "revitalize" it. Do a better job, guys, or go home and leave this as it is. You're better off getting this on Good Old Games, since it seems to work better in that version. What a shame, too, that the developers thought to mess with a title that seemed to be working fine on legacy versions of Windows.

												A blast from the past!Unlike the action-riddled, more chatoic sequel, or the nondeterministic and vague first part(not to mention its expansion), Commandos 2 has a perfect mix of everything. Encounters are usually perfectly doable in a stealthy way, but not in THE stealthy way. In my multiple playthroughs throughout the years I have found very different approaches to all the levels. Level 2, the very first time, I went all the way around the camp instead of just going through the minefield. Level 3, I bet few people even know about the underwater tunnels linking the patches of water.Your performance is rated after every level, and you get a 1-5 star ranking for things like secondary objectives fulfilled, areas discovered(remember those underwater tunnels), and enemies neutralized. And enemies neutralized without shooting. And enemies neutralized without killing. So those medalhunters must knock out entire camps by punching them in the head from behind. Humm... There is some critical amount of enemies needed for 5 stars, and the others can be molotov cocktailed, machine gunned, land mined, and knifed, but you don't know this amount.Moving an elephant, and bonus mission 2, seem nearly impossible until you find out that all vehicles(and animals) should be operated with the arrow keys.Sure, there are some glitches and odd stuff that no Steam release can cure (I don't even know what the differences with the legacy version are). Bound and gagged people can instantly get up and run away if a dangerous vehicle is approaching. Patrolmen can sometimes not be knocked out, all the punching does is alert him to your presence. And that one time I quicksaved while two men were peering into the same building, unfortunately led to an always-crash situation. Mission restart.+: kill nazis.
